newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Senior China officials to tour Taiwan despite row.
newsitem.headline: Senior China officials to tour Taiwan despite row.

text.p: A group of senior Chinese officials will visit Taiwan in February despite a 19-month-old freeze in unofficial relations between Taipei and the rival communist mainland, the Taiwan hosts said on Tuesday.

The delegation arriving on February 20 would include Wang Xiaomin, daughter-in-law of one of China's most influential elders, retired parliament chief and Communist Party politburo member Wan Li, the sponsoring Chinese Youth International said.

Wang, who will act as adviser to the semiofficial All-China Youth Federation, is a key member of Beijing's apparatus for dealings with rival Taiwan as deputy director of the exchange bureau of the communist cabinet's Taiwan Affairs Office.

She will visit privately but is expected to meet informally with officials of Taiwan's exiled Republic of China government as well as the Straits Exchange Foundation, a state-funded body formed for such cross-strait contacts.

The trip would precede by several weeks an expected visit by Tibetan Buddhism's exiled god-king, the Dalai Lama, who, like Taiwan's Nationalist leaders, is seen as a "splittist" seeking to break from the Chinese motherland.
Beijing views Taiwan and Tibet as parts of China.

Wang and a 20-member team led by Bayinqolu, a vice president of the All-China Youth Federation and official of the Communist Youth League of China, were invited by the Taiwan youth organisation for an eight-day visit, a spokeswoman said.
Nineteen months ago, China clamped a freeze on what had been slowly warming unofficial talks with Taiwan, which Beijing has seen as a renegade province since a civil war divided them in 1949.

Despite the freeze, since mid-1996 Taiwan has entertained a broad range of senior officials from China's central and provincial governments -- most of whom had never been allowed to visit the Nationalist-ruled island in the past.
Taiwan officials said the flurry of visits indicated that Beijing had relaxed restrictions on visits by mainland officials whose responsibilities touch on Taiwan.
